portfolio.title: My Work
portfolio.description: I’m a Product Designer who turns headaches into delight. With a background in front-end development and a belief that good design starts with conversations, I simplify complex workflows so tools support people, not the other way around. Currently, I craft CMS design solutions as a Senior UX/UI Designer @ Yext

resume.title: My Experience
resume.description: As a Product Designer, I turn headaches into delight. With a background in front-end development and a belief that good design starts with conversations, I simplify complex workflows so tools support people, not the other way around.

about.title: Let's connect!
about.description: Hi, I’m Ming. I believe designers are the dot-connectors of the world. We can zoom out to spot patterns in the big picture, while also zooming in to shape small moments that spark joy. We unify not just digital experiences, but also the people behind them to focus on real user needs on the other side of the screen. Whether you are a fellow tech ethusiast or recruiter, I'd love to connect and explore how we might collaborate!

projectData.projectDescription: Help hoteliers of luxuery resorts manage their Hotels' Digital Presence via a custom data editing and analytics dashboard

projectContent.sectionDescription: Accor is a hospitality group with over 45 brands and 5,600 hotels.

blockBulletPoints: Accor uses Yext’s content management system to manage their hotels’ digital presence.
Hotel managers input hotel-specific information to their Yext-powered dashboard.
Next, Yext distributes the information to listing publishers such as Google, Bing, and Apple.
The existing dashboard was built to launch quickly. The project team utilized out-of-the-box UI components without any enhancement it to meet Accor’s user needs.
Stakeholders voiced that part of the existing dashboard isn't as intuitive as it could be.
With the goal of improving clarity and increasing user engagement, the project team set out to build a new dashboard.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: Users who manage individual hotels.
blockBulletPoints: Knows all of the ins and outs of a specific hotel, including services and amenities offered.
Oversees the hotel restaurants and spas and want to manage the listings of these additional amenities.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: Users who oversee the performance of multiple hotels that fall under the same brand or region.
blockBulletPoints: Prioritizes seeing aggregated performance across regions
Cares about the performance of individual hotels.

projectContent.sectionHeading: What was the problem with existing solution?
projectContent.sectionDescription: We collected user feedback via a short survey to discover existing user pain points. I also conducted a heuristic audit with the goal of simplifying the dashboard for low-tech users. Based on the research, we discovered the following painpoints:

infoBlocks.blockDescription: Some hotel managers, especially those less familiar with technology, found the dashboard difficult to navigate. Their feedback revealed confusion about where to look and how to complete key actions.

The ability to filter the dashboard view was scattered across different modules. Each module had its own filtering dropdown (Hotel vs. country vs. brand), navigating the scope of data was extremely difficult.

infoBlocks.blockHeading: Not All Fields Are Created Equal
infoBlocks.blockDescription: There are over hundreds of fields that positively impact a hotel’s ranking in search engines. A field can be as specific as whether a hotel has vending machines. Since some fields are more impactful than others (private beach vs. vending machines), users wanted to know which ones to prioritize.
In the older dashboard, all users, regardless of responsibilities shared the same view. However, not all metrics were equally important to different types of users.
End users were hotel experts but are not SEO experts. They wanted to know how to interpret the information and how it impacted their hotel’s performance.
The field grouping offered a high-level overview of fields. Within each category, user still needed to scan a long list of seemingly-random fields.

projectContent.sectionDescription: For users to access the information they needed quickly, we explore alternative ways to group and filter metrics on the dashboard.

blockBulletPoints: The types of metrics that are available vary at hotel, country, and brand level.
I conducted whiteboarding session to explore different information architecture for displaying the data: grouping modules by hotel level or by metric type.

projectContent.sectionDescription: To help users skip some fields and find the desired ones more quickly, we reorganized the field grouping and introduced additional sub-categories to support clearer mental models.

blockBulletPoints: When I dove into reorganizing the listing field group, a card-sorting exercise immediately came to mind. However, to ask Hotel managers to take time out of their busy schedules and sort though hundreds of fields seemed unrealistic, so I settled on secondary research.
I compared Accor’s corporate domain, other large hotel chains, and Google My Business listing views to identify ways that other chains categorized hotel and room services
I researched field definitions to master industry terminology and created tooltips to help hoteliers better map each field to their hotels' amentities

projectContent.sectionDescription: To promote further actions by the hotel managers to improve hotel's digital performance, we added a net-new "Next Step" module.

blockBulletPoints: I identified 5 distinct next steps and crafted specific UX copies to highlight and distinguish the different messagings.

To ensure each call-to-action is intutive and fitting into the context that it is displayed, I defined the displaying logic behind each message so they only appear in the dashboard view where the related metrics are displayed.

projectContent.sectionDescription: To help users know which fields will have the most impact on their hotel performance, we developed a visual system to communicate different impact levels. We explored three concepts and ultimately chose the second option for its clear messaging, best use of colors, and conciseness.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: The option is straightforward but doesn't visually distinguish the levels from each other.
We picked this option for its clear messaging, best use of colors, and conciseness.
Dots alone don’t convey enough meaning, but adding text labels introduces visual clutter.

projectContent.sectionDescription: To help hoteliers better understand how their completion rate, we added a tooltip to establish benchmarks for hotel managers.

blockBulletPoints: Color indicators were used to convey urgency.
The tooltip is embeded alongside every occurrence of the completion rate metric to educate users at every opportunity.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: Dedicated a module are created for each distinct type of metric. Filters are consolidated at the top of the dashboard. Users can customize their dashboard view using the filters based on their role and goals all at once.
Carefully crafted tooltips are seen throughout the dashboard to help educate users on what they are looking at and why it is important for them.
Next-step suggestions are provided to guide the users towards impactful actions and improve hotels' online presence.
Fields reorganized and meticulously grouped into sub-categories to help users quickly find what they need.
The impact level of each field on their digital performance is added. The color-coded labels help users prioritize which fields to complete.

projectContent.sectionDescription: The initial phase of the project is complete, with encouraging feedback from end users highlighting its value.

infoBlocks.blockHeading: Putting aggregated data under the All tab is a very good idea and much more readable.
infoBlocks.blockDescription: — Laurance

infoBlocks.blockHeading: Being able to filter by countries and brand is very useful. It would be great to filter by city as well.
infoBlocks.blockDescription: — Maamar

projectContent.sectionDescription: Among the feedback, however, we also recieved request to further enhance the dashboard. These feedback will be addressed in the upcoming product iteractions.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: User feedback revealed that they want to understand the data in the analytic modules, interpret visualizations, and know what actions to take next. Users also expressed interest in seeing more dynamic data and being able to compare changes across longer time periods.
With the improved filtering experience, users are now requesting even more flexibility, such as the ability to manually select a custom subset of hotels to view aggregated performance.

projectData.projectName: Merrill Bank of America Financial Advisor Pages Redesign & Dashboard
projectData.projectDescription: Revamp Merrill's advisor marketing pages while enhancing platform solution that enables advisors to efficiently manage the content on their pages.

projectContent.sectionDescription: Merrill leverages the Yext platform to efficiently manage thousands of financial advisor listings and web pages.

blockBulletPoints: Three distinct lines of business, each requiring tailored branding and specifications.
The team is developing a series of page templates and a content management dashboard, including advisor, teams, and branch pages.
This solution will showcase each advisor’s financial services while empowering them to effortlessly manage their website content.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: who are browsing the sites for a perspective advisors or contacting their existing advisors
who want to market themselves to prospective customers and manage the content on their personal or team sites.

projectContent.sectionHeading: How are users currently interacting with the site, according to traffic data?

infoBlocks.blockDescription: Scroll analysis revealed that visitors don’t reach 25% of the advisor page, making above-the-fold content critical.
Jumplink navigation recieves the most clicks acorss all interactive elements on the page, indicating that they are a preferred way to navigate the page.
'Contact Us' and 'Request Appointment' buttons are the most clicked CTAs, though both lead to similar forms that contain identical fields.
Perspectives are drawn to advisors with awards and accolades. These sites get more clicks and views of their website.

projectContent.sectionHeading: UX issues we identified from the existing experience

blockBulletPoints: Users experienced a few seconds of a blank screen during their first visit. Google PageSpeed Insights confirmed high First Contentful Paint times on both desktop and mobile.
It takes 8-10 scrolls to reach the bottom of the page. Several text-heavy sections  are making the page longer, contributing to low engagement at the bottom.
Hero designs feature large images that push advisor names and addresses below the fold.
Background images with overlaid text or additional images in multiple sections reduced readability and sometimes obscured advisors' headshots.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: Many advisors have busy schedules and prefer a mix of well-written boilerplate content and customizable sections on their pages
Team portraits can vary in size and aspect ratio, so advisors want several hero design options to accommodate these differences.

infoBlocks.blockHeading: Needs multiple ways to feature awards
infoBlocks.blockDescription: Some accolades are awarded to individual advisors, while others are given to the entire team. Advisors want to showcase both types of recognition on their pages.

projectContent.sectionDescription: Condensed content by uitilizing tabbed section and carousel on the page to reduce page length.
Combined the “Contact Us” and “Request Appointment” calls-to-action into a single, prominent CTA to enhance user engagement.
Updated the section showcasing advisors' accolades for better visibility.
Curated reusable design components for different templates and breakpoints.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: Our team successfully launched 15000+ advisors sites.
Reduced page length by 60%, optimizing content through efficient UI patterns and minimizing scroll.
Increased 'Contact Us' form completion rate by 50%

projectContent.sectionDescription: The team wants to implement a site creation wizard, allowing advisors to easily create their own sites. Previously, this required contacting Yext to set up a new team site.

projectContent.sectionHeading: What's the desired site creation process and approval flow?

infoBlocks.blockDescription: To create a site, the team owner has to first find and add other advisor to create a new team.
They then need to provide profile information for that new team.
After the team creation request is submitted, it goes through an approval process.
Once a team is created, advisors cannot delete the team. They need to contect Yext support team to make the request

UnusedProjects.projectDescription: Create 6 website templates that help hundreds of dentists partners maintain their digital presence and create analytics dashboard to help Heartland marketing team improve site and listing performances.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: Managing a dental practice involves numerous responsibilities. Effective marketing is a crucial aspect. However, these non-dental-related tasks can often divert dentists' attention from their primary focus—caring for patients. The project aims to help hundreds of dentists Heartland partners reduce their workload of maintaining their digital presence.

projectContent.sectionDescription: There are multiple stakeholders to consider in the design process, each benefiting from various aspects of the solution:

infoBlocks.blockDescription: who are browsing the sites for a new dentist or booking follow-up visits with their existing providers
who seek greater customization options for content on their sites
who are active managing dentists' listsings and websites

blockBulletPoints: To gain a deeper understanding of business operations, requirements, and goals, participated in multiple requirements sessions with the client team.
I led brainstorming sessions with the client's key contacts to clearly define the problem, identify technical challenges, and develop a comprehensive solution.
I mapped out user flows to visualize the process of launching a new site within the platform.
Using the client-provided design brief, the design team and I created distinct style guides for each template, defining typography and color usage.
I collaborated with developers to dynamically mapping content and color variables to the templates, customizing them for each dental office's branding.
To ensure the templates can work with various branding colors without code change, I created Figma variables to test color application, accessibility, and dark mode functionality.
To highlight data variability to developers while minimizing the number of components, I carefully organized, defined, and reused design components
Developed high-fidelity mockups and implemented a scalable file structure for long-term maintainability.
We successfully launched over 1,700 dentist websites using five of the six available templates.
In 2024, the dental office sites collectively garnered 3.94 million views.
In the same year, the websites generated over 172,000 appointment bookings, indicating that 4.3% of users chose to book an appointment through the site.

UnusedProjects.projectName: Trane Supply Products & Parts Search Site
UnusedProjects.projectDescription: Design an e-commerce search experience that helps field agents and customers efficiently find products or parts to place orders

projectContent.sectionDescription: With millions of products, accessing information was cumbersome. Agents had to navigate multiple databases, manually connecting dots to find details. This project aims to transform the e-commerce site, streamlining part-finding for a seamless shopping experience for HVAC agents and customers.

projectContent.sectionHeading: Who were the users we were trying to help?

infoBlocks.blockDescription: who interact with customers over the phone
who engage with customers in person
or companies who purchase parts from Trane.
who are interested in purchasing parts from Trane

blockBulletPoints: Product information was hosted in separate databases and on different platforms. Agents had to log into multiple platforms and connect the dots manually to find the product they are looking for.
This clunky setup requires an agent to have extensive and percise knowledge of where each piece of data is located and how to find them.
To gain deeper market insights, we also conducted a competitive analysis of direct competitors
We identified common layouts and design patterns across their competitors.
Starting with user stories, the entire project team met to gather business requirements, discuss user needs, business goals, and define the technical details for upcoming features.
Outlined and crafted user flows chart for each user story.
Presented user flows with hifi mockups to shareholders
Collaborated closely with engineers and project managers to define the scope, discuss technical solutions, and identify potential challenges.
As more design mockups are designed, I have regular check-ups with engineers to seek alignment
Led and participated brainstorming sessions
Empowered our four-member design team to address challenging design requests and generate design solutions.
Worked with client's UX researchers to design user feedback questions
Participated in usability study sessions to test out hi-fidelity mockups with end users

infoBlocks.blockDescription: In 2024, our enhanced search platform handled over 9.4 million searches.
To streamline and simplify the product-finding journey, we created a search experience that consolidates related information from multiple databases into a single, cohesive web interface.
Reduced the time it takes for agents and customers to find products parts.

UnusedProjects.projectName: The UPS Store Mircrosite & Search Redesign
UnusedProjects.projectDescription: Revamp the UPS Store Microsite template including the location page, service page and search site to streamline the user experience, minimizing friction in the UI and enhancing navigation.
UnusedProjects.projectProblem: The UPS Store currently hosts its locatiomn microsites on Yext Platform. Each location includes a homepage and a set of location-specific service pages. Although the site has performed steadily over the past few years, The UPS Store is now looking for opportunities to enhance the site and improve the user experience.

blockBulletPoints: Examined the UPS Store search site using heuristic evaluation and web analytics
Conducted user testing on the UPS Store search site
Built audit reports based on the user testing result
Provided design recommendations based on the report insights

infoBlocks.blockHeading: Location Microsite UX Audits & Competitive Analysis
infoBlocks.blockDescription: For the location microsite, our team conducted an in-house competitive analysis. The UPS team also provided us with a third-party heuristic audit.

infoBlocks.blockHeading: Search Site UX Audits & Usability Testing
infoBlocks.blockDescription: For the search site, our team conducted an in-house site analytics, usability testing, and heuristic audit of the search site.

blockBulletPoints: The inbound site navigation is confusing to users. Multiple header links lead to the same page content.
The complete list of services offered at each location is buried lower on the page. As a result, customers have difficulties figuring out whether a location offer a specific service.
The site branding differs significantly from the brand’s main domain UPS.com

The search result only returns information about the current UPS store. This scope of the search, however, is not obvious to users. Customers are searching for non-location-specific information such as store finders or career at UPS
No-result screens are sometimes unhelpful. Search UI would state that filtering to another topic will return a matching result when we know the database doesn’t contain the relevant content.
The lack of search loading indication prompts users to refresh the page, especially at a slower page load speed.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: Based on the data insight, I worked with another designer to devise a redesign plan with the following improvement:
blockBulletPoints: Analyzing search data showed that users typically seek services near their physical location. To accommodate this behavior, we expanded the search scope to display results beyond a single location, prioritizing services closest to the user. We also introduced a 'My Store' button, automatically set to the nearest location, enabling users to refine search results based on their preferred store.
To improve site navigation, we repositioned the breadcrumbs above the header, clearly indicating that the content on the site is specific to the current UPS office.

We revamped the above-the-fold desig  to make accessing services easier. Users can now quickly find relevant services with a single click on the 'Services' Tab without needing to scroll through the entire page.

infoBlocks.blockDescription: I updated the design based on our insights. Our project team then met with the client every week to gather feedback and improve the designs.

blockBulletPoints: Identified key areas for UX improvement on the page.
Built trust with the client by understanding their business needs and design requirements.
